Mt, rico Received 17 March 1997: received in revised form 8 September 1997: accepted 8 September 1997 Abstract Alkylation of benzene with isopropanol to produce cumene was investigated using a MCM-41 aluminosilicate as catalyst. The MCM-41/)-AI203 catalyst, activated by means of a liquid extraction method, mainly contained strong Lewis acid sites. After the activity of the composite catalyst was stabilized, it was observed that. in the isopropylation of benzene, cumene was the major product. The high cumene selectivity could be due to the low acid site concentration in the MCM-41 material, and the rapid diffusion of cumene in the broad channels of this mesoporous framework. ~ 1998 Elsevier Science B.V. Introduction Shape-selective conversions of benzene and toluene alkylation over zeolite catalysts have been extensively studied [ol-3]. Medium-pore zeolites (pore diameter 4.0-5.6 A), for example, ZSM-5 and ZSM-35 have already been used in several of those processes due to their advantages [4,51. Nevertheless, there are a few studies concerning the selective conversions on MCM-41 material [6,7], which is a novel mesoporous molecular sieve. The MCM-41 structure possesses a hexagonal array of uniform mesopores in the 20- 100 A range. This material can incorporate AI species *Corresponding author. In this paper, we report the application of activated MCM-41 material for the catalytic alkylation of ben- zene with isopropanol to produce cumene, which is used as monomer for preparation of special polymers. We choose this alkylation process as a good test reaction fl)r selectivity studies. 2. Experimental 2.1. Synthesis of MCM-41 ah,minosilicate MCM-41 was synthesized according to the litera- ture [8]It was prepared using Catapal alumina as the 388 J. Medina-Valtierra et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 166 (1998) 387-392 source of aluminium. The molar composition in the hydrogel was: 30SiO2-A1_~O3-4.2 (TMA)20-9.4HDTMABr-298H20. Crystallization of the gels was carried out in a 300 ml stainless steel autoclave at 150C for 24 h. After the autoclave was cooled, the product was filtered, washed with deionized water, and dried at room temperature overnight (sample TAME3/L). To obtain the active form of this aluminosilicate, the as- synthesized sample was calcined in a static muffle at 30OC for 3 h. Then, it was washed twice with an ethanol/l N NH4NO3 solution (1 g/10 ml, 25% vol. of nitrate) at 80C for 1 h. Finally, the dry solid was calcined again at 550:C for 3 h to burn offthe remnant organic template (sample TAME3/E). Previous results suggested that a limited number of Al-species interact strongly with the template, therefore the last template removes or modifies these Ai-species [9]. This effect could decrease the acidity of thc final catalytic material. 2.2. Preparation of the composite catalyst The MCM-41 aluminosilicate was mixed with appropriate quantities of boehmite, nitric acid and distilled water, such that the MCM-41 :v-alumina ratio was 40 : 60 in the final extrudate. The extrudates (1/16 in) were calcined in a furnace in static atmo- sphere at 500:C for 3 h. This catalytic material is called CATZ-4. 2.3. Characterization and catalytic evaluation All samples were characterized by X-ray diffrac- tion, XRD (Siemens D500, CuK,,), IR spectroscopy with adsorbed pyridine (Nicolet FTIR 710) and ammonia temperature-programmed desorption, TPD-NH3 (Altamira analyzer). Texture parameters of TAME3/E and CATZ-4 were determined from the adsorption isotherms of nitrogen at 75 K. The adsorption isotherms were measured with an Accu- sorb 2100 E instrument. Six grams of the active catalyst were loaded in the reactor, which is a fixed bed placed in a stainless steel tube. Catalytic evaluations were performed at atmo- spheric pressure. The mixture of benzene and isopro- panol was fed using a syringe pump, vaporized in the preheater, and passed through the reactor with the catalyst maintained at the reaction temperature. The products were trapped in a condenser at the reactor outlet and analyzed by gas chromatography (SR1 instrumcnts 9610) using FID and a 0.25 mm 60 mm DB-5 capillary column. In some of the runs at high temperatures, the gaseous products were collected and identified. 3. As seen in Table 1, the CATZ-4 catalyst was active and selective for alkylation to produce cumene. This is very important given that there is little evidence of the selective nature of these meso- porous materials in aromatic alkylations [6,7,16]. These surprising results suggest that a higher cumene disproportionation rate occurred to give mainly meta and ortho-DIPB at higher temperatures: 2 cumene - diisopropylbenzene This reaction scheme has been proposed by Kaeding [17]. Since there should be negligible steric hindrance in the formation of any of the three isomers in the mesopores of MCM-41 framework, there is no good explanation for the low para-DIPB selectivity nor the relatively large anaounts of ortho-DIPB. In addition, other side reactions such as polyalkyl- benzenes formation and cracking took place at high temperatures. These side reactions were confirmed by the presence of triisopropylbenzenes at 350 :C, and by the presence of notable amounts of C2-C~ products at higher temperatures. Since there are broad channels (>40 A) in the MCM-41 structure, it is expected that spatial con- straints do not occur in the formation of products. According to the data presented here, it does not appear that selectivity is very much affected by the change in space velocity. It seems that enhanced cumene selectivity is not related so much to diffu- sional effects but more to the fact that the MCM-41 material contains relatively few acid sites compared with microporous zeolites. 4. Conclusions Cumene is formed as the primary product of iso- propylation, which does not easily react to form DIPB due to the lower probability of further reaction. There- lore, it was interesting to lind that with MCM-41 catalyst, cumene was the main product. An important side reaction was the cumene disproponionation to give toluene ~- ETB or DIPB isomers in concentra- tions far lower than their thermodynamic cquilibrium. In this case, the primary product of alkylation diffuses into the broad channels when they react slowly, Since larger molecules such as aikylnaphthalenes can dif- fuse easily in the mesopore channel of MCM-41 I I 8], we conclude that the main products detected are those favoured kinetically at the active sites. Although these results are preliminary, they demonstrate the potential of MCM-41 material as a selective catalyst for certain alkylation reactions. References Ill w.w. Kaeding, C. Chu. L.B. Young. B.
